shortdesc.p: Manual mode is the basic setting for all photographers and can be adjusted to accommodate various lighting conditions. You should adjust Manual mode settings accordingly to the amount of light present in a dark or bright environment. This allows for consistency within you photographs as exposure settings stay intact throughout lighting changes in your environment.

shortdesc.p: Manual mode consists of three beasic exposure settings: ISO, Aperture, and Shutter Speed

shortdesc.p: By adjusting the ISO, the camera sensor becomes more or less sensitive to light. DSLRs typically have an ISO range of 100 (low sensitivity) to 12,800 (high sensitivity). A high ISO will create a brighter photograph, with a grainer image. A low ISO will yield a sharper and darker image.

shortdesc.p: By modifying the aperture, you are widening or narrowing the camera lens. The aperture is measured by the f-stop. A higher f-stop (near f/2.8) will allow for a narrower lens and will create a darker image. A lower f-stop (near f/16) will allow a wider lens opening with more depth to the image.

shortdesc.p: By determing the shutter speed, you are increasing or decreasing the camera's exposures to light. The duration of time is measured as fractions of a second. A faster speed of 1/200-second will create a darker image, whereas a slower shutter speed of ½-second will yield a lighter image.
